```{python}
from IPython.display import Markdown

def why_geojupyter(active: int | None = None) -> str:
  """Display the repeated "Why GeoJupyter" slide content."""
  items = [
    "Even experts often struggle",
    "Rich storytelling is only for the privileged",
    "Friction when visualizing from a programming environment",
  ]
  lst = []
  for index, item in enumerate(items):
    if active is None:
      lst.append(f"* {item}")
    elif index == active:
      lst.append(f"* **{item}**")
    elif index < active:
      lst.append(f"* [~~{item}~~]{{.fade}}")
    elif index > active:
      lst.append(f"* [{item}]{{.fade}}")

  return Markdown(f"""
:face_with_head_bandage: Existing workflows are sometimes painfully imperfect.

{"\n".join(lst)}
""")
```

## :people_holding_hands: GeoJupyter is a community!

![GeoJupyter is **not** software; it's a **community** which will build many things together!](/assets/images/venn-diagram.svg)

:::notes
As another refresher, GeoJupyter is a community-directed effort to reimagine geospatial
interactive computing experiences _with the power of the Jupyter architecture_.
The project has many components including software, education, and
cross-collaboration with other communities.

**JupyterGIS** is our flagship project, led by QuantStack, and that's what I'll focus on today!
:::


## JupyterGIS: What's the big idea?

:::evenly-spaced
:artist: **Human-centered**, participatory design

:open_hands: **Open source** and **open science**

:cartwheeling: **Approachability** and **playfulness**, like graphical GIS tools

:feather: **Flexibility** and **reproducibility**, like coding methods

:performing_arts: **Collaboration** and **storytelling**, like Jupyter Notebooks
:::

:::notes
The idea behind JupyterGIS is to apply GeoJupyter community values, including
participatory design (allowing users to lead the way), and enabling open
science, to unify the good stuff from three areas of geospatial computing to
unlock new workflows.

We want the **approachability** and **playfulness** of graphical and desktop GIS tools;
the **flexibility** and **reproducibility** of coding or scripting methods;
and the **collaboration** and **storytelling** of the Jupyter ecosystem.
:::


---

![You got your desktop GIS experience in my coding environment!](/assets/images/chocolate-peanut-butter.jpg)

:::notes
These values have historically been prioritized in separate tools and
techniques, but we believe they go together like chocolate and peanut butter!

We also believe that the only way to succeed at this is for software engineers
and geospatial data practitioners to empathize and collaborate with each other.
:::

## :shrug: Why GeoJupyter?

```{python}
why_geojupyter(2)
```

:::notes
Another challenge that we've heard widely reported by users is friction when
visualizing data about our planet from a programming environment, like a
Jupyter Notebook.

We've found many practitioners are perfectly comfortable writing code for
analysis, but visualizing data is an entirely different skill from analysis.
There's a wide variety of visualization libraries with unique and sometimes
frustrating interfaces.
It can be hard to choose, and each choice has a tradeoff.
Depending on the chosen library, practitioners may struggle to visualize many
datasets together, or to interact with the visualization in a meaningful way,
or to control the details of the visualization.

To get around this, practitioners described a process with many steps, like a dance.
We heard this so often that we gave it a name: "The GIS Bounce".
:::


## :woman_dancing: _The GIS Bounce_ :man_dancing: (hard mode) {.smaller}

::::::columns
:::{.column width=65%}
:abacus: Do some analysis

:floppy_disk: Write out a data file

:inbox_tray: Download it to local machine

:world_map: "Bounce" to QGIS, load basemap, load data file

:eyes: Validate, inspect, explore

:shower: "Bounce" back to Notebook and repeat
:::

:::{.column width=35%}
![](/assets/images/gis-bounce-hard.jpg)
:::
::::::

:::notes
To do the GIS bounce:

First, do some analysis.
Then, write out a data file to check your work so far.
If you're working in a cloud environment, download that data file.
"Bounce" over to QGIS, load up a basemap, and then finally load your data.
Now you can do your validation and "bounce" back to your notebook, and repeat!

That's a lot of steps, and they are repeated every time many practitioners
check their work -- a common and critical task.

Checking our work shouldn't be frustrating and time-consuming, it should be
seamless, joyful, and rewarding.
:::


<!-- alex ignore easy -->
## :woman_dancing: _The GIS Bounce_ :man_dancing: (easy mode) {.smaller}

::::::columns
:::{.column width=65%}
:abacus: Do some analysis

:snake: "Bounce" to graphical GIS: 1 LOC!

(Imports don't count :smirk:)

```python
from ... import explore

explore(
  my_xarray_dataarray,
  {'data': my_geodataframe, 'symbology': 'choropleth'},
)
```

:eyes: Validate, inspect, explore

:shower: "Bounce" back to Notebook and repeat
:::

:::{.column width=35%}
![](/assets/images/gis-bounce-easy.jpg)
:::
::::::

:::notes
What about a nice interface that can display your many geospatial data sources
as layers in a Jupyter widget with some sensible symbology by default?

In this example, we pass in some gridded data with no settings, and some
polygon data with a request to display it as a chorolpleth map.

We built something like this in JupyterGIS, and we're continuing to evolve the idea.
:::

## What is JupyterGIS? How is it different?

:::notes
_Read the slide_
:::

:::incremental
* Interactive GIS environment
* JupyterLab- and browser-native (try it in a JupyterHub!)
* Python API for Notebook integration
* Supports QGIS project files
* **_Real-time collaboration_**: like Google Docs, but on a map!
:::

. . .

:::notes
Let's take a look at some of the things we can do with JupyterGIS.
:::

:house: All under one familiar roof (JupyterLab)!


## Explore data

![Inspecting attributes of a building footprint ([eo science for society blog](https://eo4society.esa.int/2025/10/16/jupytergis-breaks-through-to-the-next-level/))](/assets/images/jupytergis-identify.jpg)

:::notes
We can explore datasets interactively -- here we are inspecting attributes of a buildings dataset.
:::


## Process data

![Calculating convex hulls of regions of France ([eo science for society blog](https://eo4society.esa.int/2025/10/16/jupytergis-breaks-through-to-the-next-level/))](/assets/images/jupytergis-processing.jpg)

:::notes
We can perform data processing operations in a visual environment -- here we've calculated convex hulls of regions of France.
:::


## Browse curated layers

![The JupyterGIS layer browser](/assets/images/jupytergis-layer-browser.jpg)

:::notes
We can add layers to our map from a curated layer browser.
:::


## Discover data with STAC (WIP)

![Browsing a STAC catalog in JupyterGIS ([eo science for society blog](https://eo4society.esa.int/2025/10/16/jupytergis-breaks-through-to-the-next-level/))](https://eo4society.esa.int/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/screenshot-5.png)

:::notes
We can discover data using Spatio Temporal Asset Catalogs, or "STAC catalogs",
a modern standard for computer interface with data catalogs.

This is a work in progress that will continue to evolve over time!
:::


## Support for Xarray datasets

![Visualizing an Xarray dataset, tiled on-the-fly ([TiTiler](https://developmentseed.org/titiler/), [David Brochart](https://david-brochart.medium.com/create-your-own-layers-in-jupytergis-cbb995a89b16))](/assets/images/jupytergis-tiler.gif)

:::notes
Thanks to the modular Jupyter architecture, we can build extensions on
extensions to compose cool new features.

Here we're using `jupytergis-tiler` by David Brochart of Quantstack, to display
data in an Xarray dataset on-the-fly in JupyterGIS.

Under the hood, the TiTiler dynamic tile server by Development Seed is powering
this functionality.
:::


## Collaborate

![Two users collaborating in real-time on a JupyterGIS project ([QuantStack](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FzHYYCvWyu0))](/assets/images/jupytergis-collab.gif){width=100%}

:::notes
Thanks again to the modular Jupyter architecture, we can leverage
the `jupyter-collaboration` extension, which enables real-time collaboration on
Notebooks, to enable real-time collaboration on a map.

Users can leave Google Docs style comments, follow each other, and edit the map
at the same time, enabling new GIS workflows previously unavailable with free
and open source software.
:::
